instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: Going through the rails, everything above <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> is stable, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> jumps a bit when the fan pulses, from 4.89vto 5v.  Every voltage below that pulses.  Everything appears to be trying to come on.  Is there a standard way of attacking 1/4 fan spin?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: If the fan pulses then all rails will be pulsing too. Was this liquid? Is CPU Vcore pulsing too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: Yes liquid, CPU Vcore is pulsing too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: If there was liquid in the <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> area this would be a very good 1st suspect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: area had a little water damage, went ahead and cleaned up from a donor just in case. Still has the 1/4 fan spin.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> pin 8 looks like garbage, this has to be reprogrammed, correct?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 1/4 fan spin
threads.message: Yes, see if you can read the original first. ME region should be rescued if possible, you cannot just use a BIOS from another board.

threads.message: thanks Duke, on a slow boat from china to me now.
